description:
Barbatula barbatula, commonly known as the stone loach or European stone loach, is a small freshwater fish species belonging to the family Nemacheilidae. It is widely distributed throughout Europe, inhabiting streams, rivers, and lakes with cool, well-oxygenated waters.

The stone loach is a bottom-dwelling fish, typically found hiding under rocks, logs, or other submerged structures. It has a long, cylindrical body with a rounded snout and four pairs of barbels around the mouth, which give the species its common name. The coloration is typically mottled or striped, with a brownish or grayish hue, allowing the fish to blend in with its rocky habitat.

Stone loaches are small, typically reaching a maximum length of around 15 centimeters (6 inches). They are omnivorous, feeding on a variety of aquatic invertebrates, algae, and plant matter. Their diet and habitat preferences make them an important component of freshwater ecosystems, contributing to the overall biodiversity and ecological balance.

Barbatula barbatula is considered a species of least concern on the IUCN Red List, as it has a widespread distribution and is generally not facing significant threats. However, it can be sensitive to environmental changes, such as pollution, habitat degradation, and water flow alterations, which may impact its local populations.
